      92             : /* ----------
      93             :  * Pretty formatting constants
      94             :  * ----------
      95             :  */
      96             : 
      97             : /* Indent counts */
      98             : #define PRETTYINDENT_STD        8
      99             : #define PRETTYINDENT_JOIN       4
     100             : #define PRETTYINDENT_VAR        4
     101             : 
     102             : #define PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT      40  /* wrap limit */
     103             : 
     104             : /* Pretty flags */
     105             : #define PRETTYFLAG_PAREN        0x0001
     106             : #define PRETTYFLAG_INDENT       0x0002
     107             : 
     108             : /* Default line length for pretty-print wrapping: 0 means wrap always */
     109             : #define WRAP_COLUMN_DEFAULT     0
     110             : 
     111             : /* macros to test if pretty action needed */
     112             : #define PRETTY_PAREN(context)   ((context)->prettyFlags & PRETTYFLAG_PAREN)
     113             : #define PRETTY_INDENT(context)  ((context)->prettyFlags & PRETTYFLAG_INDENT)
     114             : 
     115             : 
     116             : /* ----------
     117             :  * Local data types
     118             :  * ----------
     119             :  */
     120             : 
     121             : /* Context info needed for invoking a recursive querytree display routine */
     122             : typedef struct
     123             : {
     124             :     StringInfo  buf;            /* output buffer to append to */
     125             :     List       *namespaces;     /* List of deparse_namespace nodes */
     126             :     List       *windowClause;   /* Current query level's WINDOW clause */
     127             :     List       *windowTList;    /* targetlist for resolving WINDOW clause */
     128             :     int         prettyFlags;    /* enabling of pretty-print functions */
     129             :     int         wrapColumn;     /* max line length, or -1 for no limit */
     130             :     int         indentLevel;    /* current indent level for prettyprint */
     131             :     bool        varprefix;      /* true to print prefixes on Vars */
     132             :     Oid         distrelid;      /* the distributed table being modified, if valid */
     133             :     int64       shardid;        /* a distributed table's shardid, if positive */
     134             :     ParseExprKind special_exprkind; /* set only for exprkinds needing special
     135             :                                      * handling */
     136             :     Bitmapset  *appendparents;  /* if not null, map child Vars of these relids
     137             :                                  * back to the parent rel */
     138             : } deparse_context;
     139             : 
     140             : /*
     141             :  * Each level of query context around a subtree needs a level of Var namespace.
     142             :  * A Var having varlevelsup=N refers to the N'th item (counting from 0) in
     143             :  * the current context's namespaces list.
     144             :  *
     145             :  * The rangetable is the list of actual RTEs from the query tree, and the
     146             :  * cte list is the list of actual CTEs.
     147             :  *
     148             :  * rtable_names holds the alias name to be used for each RTE (either a C
     149             :  * string, or NULL for nameless RTEs such as unnamed joins).
     150             :  * rtable_columns holds the column alias names to be used for each RTE.
     151             :  *
     152             :  * In some cases we need to make names of merged JOIN USING columns unique
     153             :  * across the whole query, not only per-RTE.  If so, unique_using is true
     154             :  * and using_names is a list of C strings representing names already assigned
     155             :  * to USING columns.
     156             :  *
     157             :  * When deparsing plan trees, there is always just a single item in the
     158             :  * deparse_namespace list (since a plan tree never contains Vars with
     159             :  * varlevelsup > 0).  We store the PlanState node that is the immediate
     160             :  * parent of the expression to be deparsed, as well as a list of that
     161             :  * PlanState's ancestors.  In addition, we store its outer and inner subplan
     162             :  * state nodes, as well as their plan nodes' targetlists, and the index tlist
     163             :  * if the current plan node might contain INDEX_VAR Vars.  (These fields could
     164             :  * be derived on-the-fly from the current PlanState, but it seems notationally
     165             :  * clearer to set them up as separate fields.)
     166             :  */
     167             : typedef struct
     168             : {
     169             :     List       *rtable;         /* List of RangeTblEntry nodes */
     170             :     List       *rtable_names;   /* Parallel list of names for RTEs */
     171             :     List       *rtable_columns; /* Parallel list of deparse_columns structs */
     172             :     List       *subplans;       /* List of Plan trees for SubPlans */
     173             :     List       *ctes;           /* List of CommonTableExpr nodes */
     174             :     AppendRelInfo **appendrels; /* Array of AppendRelInfo nodes, or NULL */
     175             :     /* Workspace for column alias assignment: */
     176             :     bool        unique_using;   /* Are we making USING names globally unique */
     177             :     List       *using_names;    /* List of assigned names for USING columns */
     178             :     /* Remaining fields are used only when deparsing a Plan tree: */
     179             :     Plan       *plan;           /* immediate parent of current expression */
     180             :     List       *ancestors;      /* ancestors of planstate */
     181             :     Plan       *outer_plan;     /* outer subnode, or NULL if none */
     182             :     Plan       *inner_plan;     /* inner subnode, or NULL if none */
     183             :     List       *outer_tlist;    /* referent for OUTER_VAR Vars */
     184             :     List       *inner_tlist;    /* referent for INNER_VAR Vars */
     185             :     List       *index_tlist;    /* referent for INDEX_VAR Vars */
     186             :     /* Special namespace representing a function signature: */
     187             :     char       *funcname;
     188             :     int         numargs;
     189             :     char      **argnames;
     190             : } deparse_namespace;
     191             : 
     192             : /* Callback signature for resolve_special_varno() */
     193             : typedef void (*rsv_callback) (Node *node, deparse_context *context,
     194             :                               void *callback_arg);
     195             : 
     196             : /*
     197             :  * Per-relation data about column alias names.
     198             :  *
     199             :  * Selecting aliases is unreasonably complicated because of the need to dump
     200             :  * rules/views whose underlying tables may have had columns added, deleted, or
     201             :  * renamed since the query was parsed.  We must nonetheless print the rule/view
     202             :  * in a form that can be reloaded and will produce the same results as before.
     203             :  *
     204             :  * For each RTE used in the query, we must assign column aliases that are
     205             :  * unique within that RTE.  SQL does not require this of the original query,
     206             :  * but due to factors such as *-expansion we need to be able to uniquely
     207             :  * reference every column in a decompiled query.  As long as we qualify all
     208             :  * column references, per-RTE uniqueness is sufficient for that.
     209             :  *
     210             :  * However, we can't ensure per-column name uniqueness for unnamed join RTEs,
     211             :  * since they just inherit column names from their input RTEs, and we can't
     212             :  * rename the columns at the join level.  Most of the time this isn't an issue
     213             :  * because we don't need to reference the join's output columns as such; we
     214             :  * can reference the input columns instead.  That approach can fail for merged
     215             :  * JOIN USING columns, however, so when we have one of those in an unnamed
     216             :  * join, we have to make that column's alias globally unique across the whole
     217             :  * query to ensure it can be referenced unambiguously.
     218             :  *
     219             :  * Another problem is that a JOIN USING clause requires the columns to be
     220             :  * merged to have the same aliases in both input RTEs, and that no other
     221             :  * columns in those RTEs or their children conflict with the USING names.
     222             :  * To handle that, we do USING-column alias assignment in a recursive
     223             :  * traversal of the query's jointree.  When descending through a JOIN with
     224             :  * USING, we preassign the USING column names to the child columns, overriding
     225             :  * other rules for column alias assignment.  We also mark each RTE with a list
     226             :  * of all USING column names selected for joins containing that RTE, so that
     227             :  * when we assign other columns' aliases later, we can avoid conflicts.
     228             :  *
     229             :  * Another problem is that if a JOIN's input tables have had columns added or
     230             :  * deleted since the query was parsed, we must generate a column alias list
     231             :  * for the join that matches the current set of input columns --- otherwise, a
     232             :  * change in the number of columns in the left input would throw off matching
     233             :  * of aliases to columns of the right input.  Thus, positions in the printable
     234             :  * column alias list are not necessarily one-for-one with varattnos of the
     235             :  * JOIN, so we need a separate new_colnames[] array for printing purposes.
     236             :  */
     237             : typedef struct
     238             : {
     239             :     /*
     240             :      * colnames is an array containing column aliases to use for columns that
     241             :      * existed when the query was parsed.  Dropped columns have NULL entries.
     242             :      * This array can be directly indexed by varattno to get a Var's name.
     243             :      *
     244             :      * Non-NULL entries are guaranteed unique within the RTE, *except* when
     245             :      * this is for an unnamed JOIN RTE.  In that case we merely copy up names
     246             :      * from the two input RTEs.
     247             :      *
     248             :      * During the recursive descent in set_using_names(), forcible assignment
     249             :      * of a child RTE's column name is represented by pre-setting that element
     250             :      * of the child's colnames array.  So at that stage, NULL entries in this
     251             :      * array just mean that no name has been preassigned, not necessarily that
     252             :      * the column is dropped.
     253             :      */
     254             :     int         num_cols;       /* length of colnames[] array */
     255             :     char      **colnames;       /* array of C strings and NULLs */
     256             : 
     257             :     /*
     258             :      * new_colnames is an array containing column aliases to use for columns
     259             :      * that would exist if the query was re-parsed against the current
     260             :      * definitions of its base tables.  This is what to print as the column
     261             :      * alias list for the RTE.  This array does not include dropped columns,
     262             :      * but it will include columns added since original parsing.  Indexes in
     263             :      * it therefore have little to do with current varattno values.  As above,
     264             :      * entries are unique unless this is for an unnamed JOIN RTE.  (In such an
     265             :      * RTE, we never actually print this array, but we must compute it anyway
     266             :      * for possible use in computing column names of upper joins.) The
     267             :      * parallel array is_new_col marks which of these columns are new since
     268             :      * original parsing.  Entries with is_new_col false must match the
     269             :      * non-NULL colnames entries one-for-one.
     270             :      */
     271             :     int         num_new_cols;   /* length of new_colnames[] array */
     272             :     char      **new_colnames;   /* array of C strings */
     273             :     bool       *is_new_col;     /* array of bool flags */
     274             : 
     275             :     /* This flag tells whether we should actually print a column alias list */
     276             :     bool        printaliases;
     277             : 
     278             :     /* This list has all names used as USING names in joins above this RTE */
     279             :     List       *parentUsing;    /* names assigned to parent merged columns */
     280             : 
     281             :     /*
     282             :      * If this struct is for a JOIN RTE, we fill these fields during the
     283             :      * set_using_names() pass to describe its relationship to its child RTEs.
     284             :      *
     285             :      * leftattnos and rightattnos are arrays with one entry per existing
     286             :      * output column of the join (hence, indexable by join varattno).  For a
     287             :      * simple reference to a column of the left child, leftattnos[i] is the
     288             :      * child RTE's attno and rightattnos[i] is zero; and conversely for a
     289             :      * column of the right child.  But for merged columns produced by JOIN
     290             :      * USING/NATURAL JOIN, both leftattnos[i] and rightattnos[i] are nonzero.
     291             :      * Also, if the column has been dropped, both are zero.
     292             :      *
     293             :      * If it's a JOIN USING, usingNames holds the alias names selected for the
     294             :      * merged columns (these might be different from the original USING list,
     295             :      * if we had to modify names to achieve uniqueness).
     296             :      */
     297             :     int         leftrti;        /* rangetable index of left child */
     298             :     int         rightrti;       /* rangetable index of right child */
     299             :     int        *leftattnos;     /* left-child varattnos of join cols, or 0 */
     300             :     int        *rightattnos;    /* right-child varattnos of join cols, or 0 */
     301             :     List       *usingNames;     /* names assigned to merged columns */
     302             : } deparse_columns;
     303             : 
     304             : /* This macro is analogous to rt_fetch(), but for deparse_columns structs */
     305             : #define deparse_columns_fetch(rangetable_index, dpns) \
     306             :     ((deparse_columns *) list_nth((dpns)->rtable_columns, (rangetable_index)-1))
     307             : 
     308             : /*
     309             :  * Entry in set_rtable_names' hash table
     310             :  */
     311             : typedef struct
     312             : {
     313             :     char        name[NAMEDATALEN];  /* Hash key --- must be first */
     314             :     int         counter;        /* Largest addition used so far for name */
     315             : } NameHashEntry;
     316             : 
     317             : 
     318             : /* ----------
     319             :  * Local functions
     320             :  *
     321             :  * Most of these functions used to use fixed-size buffers to build their
     322             :  * results.  Now, they take an (already initialized) StringInfo object
     323             :  * as a parameter, and append their text output to its contents.
     324             :  * ----------
     325             :  */
     326             : static void set_rtable_names(deparse_namespace *dpns, List *parent_namespaces,
     327             :                  Bitmapset *rels_used);
     328             : static void set_deparse_for_query(deparse_namespace *dpns, Query *query,
     329             :                       List *parent_namespaces);
     330             : static bool has_dangerous_join_using(deparse_namespace *dpns, Node *jtnode);
     331             : static void set_using_names(deparse_namespace *dpns, Node *jtnode,
     332             :                 List *parentUsing);
     333             : static void set_relation_column_names(deparse_namespace *dpns,
     334             :                           RangeTblEntry *rte,
     335             :                           deparse_columns *colinfo);
     336             : static void set_join_column_names(deparse_namespace *dpns, RangeTblEntry *rte,
     337             :                       deparse_columns *colinfo);
     338             : static bool colname_is_unique(const char *colname, deparse_namespace *dpns,
     339             :                   deparse_columns *colinfo);
     340             : static char *make_colname_unique(char *colname, deparse_namespace *dpns,
     341             :                     deparse_columns *colinfo);
     342             : static void expand_colnames_array_to(deparse_columns *colinfo, int n);
     343             : static void identify_join_columns(JoinExpr *j, RangeTblEntry *jrte,
     344             :                       deparse_columns *colinfo);
     345             : static char *get_rtable_name(int rtindex, deparse_context *context);
     346             : static void set_deparse_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, Plan *plan);
     347             : static Plan *find_recursive_union(deparse_namespace *dpns,
     348             :                                   WorkTableScan *wtscan);
     349             : static void push_child_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, Plan *plan,
     350             :                 deparse_namespace *save_dpns);
     351             : static void pop_child_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns,
     352             :                deparse_namespace *save_dpns);
     353             : static void push_ancestor_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, ListCell *ancestor_cell,
     354             :                    deparse_namespace *save_dpns);
     355             : static void pop_ancestor_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns,
     356             :                   deparse_namespace *save_dpns);
     357             : static void get_query_def(Query *query, StringInfo buf, List *parentnamespace,

     359             :               int prettyFlags, int wrapColumn, int startIndent);
     360             : static void get_query_def_extended(Query *query, StringInfo buf,

     362             :                 TupleDesc resultDesc, bool colNamesVisible,
     363             :                 int prettyFlags, int wrapColumn,
     364             :                 int startIndent);
     365             : static void get_values_def(List *values_lists, deparse_context *context);

     656             : 
     657             : /*
     658             :  * set_rtable_names: select RTE aliases to be used in printing a query
     659             :  *
     660             :  * We fill in dpns->rtable_names with a list of names that is one-for-one with
     661             :  * the already-filled dpns->rtable list.  Each RTE name is unique among those
     662             :  * in the new namespace plus any ancestor namespaces listed in
     663             :  * parent_namespaces.
     664             :  *
     665             :  * If rels_used isn't NULL, only RTE indexes listed in it are given aliases.
     666             :  *
     667             :  * Note that this function is only concerned with relation names, not column
     668             :  * names.
     669             :  */
     670             : static void
     671       36690 : set_rtable_names(deparse_namespace *dpns, List *parent_namespaces,
     672             :                  Bitmapset *rels_used)
     673             : {
     674             :     HASHCTL     hash_ctl;
     675             :     HTAB       *names_hash;
     676             :     NameHashEntry *hentry;
     677             :     bool        found;
     678             :     int         rtindex;
     679             :     ListCell   *lc;
     680             : 
     681       36690 :     dpns->rtable_names = NIL;
     682             :     /* nothing more to do if empty rtable */
     683       36690 :     if (dpns->rtable == NIL)
     684        6327 :         return;
     685             : 
     686             :     /*
     687             :      * We use a hash table to hold known names, so that this process is O(N)
     688             :      * not O(N^2) for N names.
     689             :      */
     690       30363 :     hash_ctl.keysize = NAMEDATALEN;
     691       30363 :     hash_ctl.entrysize = sizeof(NameHashEntry);
     692       30363 :     hash_ctl.hcxt = CurrentMemoryContext;
     693       30363 :     names_hash = hash_create("set_rtable_names names",
     694       30363 :                              list_length(dpns->rtable),
     695             :                              &hash_ctl,
     696             :                              HASH_ELEM | HASH_STRINGS | HASH_CONTEXT);
     697             : 
     698             :     /* Preload the hash table with names appearing in parent_namespaces */
     699       54745 :     foreach(lc, parent_namespaces)
     700             :     {
     701       24382 :         deparse_namespace *olddpns = (deparse_namespace *) lfirst(lc);
     702             :         ListCell   *lc2;
     703             : 
     704      119686 :         foreach(lc2, olddpns->rtable_names)
     705             :         {
     706       95304 :             char       *oldname = (char *) lfirst(lc2);
     707             : 
     708       95304 :             if (oldname == NULL)
     709       34301 :                 continue;
     710       61003 :             hentry = (NameHashEntry *) hash_search(names_hash,
     711             :                                                    oldname,
     712             :                                                    HASH_ENTER,
     713             :                                                    &found);
     714             :             /* we do not complain about duplicate names in parent namespaces */
     715       61003 :             hentry->counter = 0;
     716             :         }
     717             :     }
     718             : 
     719             :     /* Now we can scan the rtable */
     720       30363 :     rtindex = 1;
     721       74743 :     foreach(lc, dpns->rtable)
     722             :     {
     723       44380 :         RangeTblEntry *rte = (RangeTblEntry *) lfirst(lc);
     724             :         char       *refname;
     725             : 
     726             :         /* Just in case this takes an unreasonable amount of time ... */
     727       44380 :         CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS();
     728             : 
     729       44380 :         if (rels_used && !bms_is_member(rtindex, rels_used))
     730             :         {
     731             :             /* Ignore unreferenced RTE */
     732           0 :             refname = NULL;
     733             :         }
     734       44380 :         else if (rte->alias)
     735             :         {

     737       28546 :             refname = rte->alias->aliasname;
     738             :         }
     739       15834 :         else if (rte->rtekind == RTE_RELATION)
     740             :         {
     741             :             /* Use the current actual name of the relation */
     742        2646 :             refname = get_rel_name(rte->relid);
     743             :         }
     744       13188 :         else if (rte->rtekind == RTE_JOIN)
     745             :         {
     746             :             /* Unnamed join has no refname */
     747        6532 :             refname = NULL;
     748             :         }
     749             :         else
     750             :         {
     751             :             /* Otherwise use whatever the parser assigned */
     752        6656 :             refname = rte->eref->aliasname;
     753             :         }
     754             : 
     755             :         /*
     756             :          * If the selected name isn't unique, append digits to make it so, and
     757             :          * make a new hash entry for it once we've got a unique name.  For a
     758             :          * very long input name, we might have to truncate to stay within
     759             :          * NAMEDATALEN.

     782        2195 :                             break;

     785             :                                                   refnamelen - 1);

     790             :                                                             &found);

     792        2187 :                 hentry2->counter = 0;    /* init new hash entry */

     794             :             }
     795             :             else
     796             :             {
     797             :                 /* Name not previously used, need only initialize hentry */
     798       35661 :                 hentry->counter = 0;
     799             :             }

     803       44380 :         rtindex++;

     808             : 
     809             : /*
     810             :  * set_deparse_for_query: set up deparse_namespace for deparsing a Query tree
     811             :  *
     812             :  * For convenience, this is defined to initialize the deparse_namespace struct
     813             :  * from scratch.
     814             :  */
     815             : static void
     816       36690 : set_deparse_for_query(deparse_namespace *dpns, Query *query,
     817             :                       List *parent_namespaces)
     818             : {
     819             :     ListCell   *lc;
     820             :     ListCell   *lc2;
     821             : 
     822             :     /* Initialize *dpns and fill rtable/ctes links */
     823       36690 :     memset(dpns, 0, sizeof(deparse_namespace));
     824       36690 :     dpns->rtable = query->rtable;
     825       36690 :     dpns->subplans = NIL;
     826       36690 :     dpns->ctes = query->cteList;
     827       36690 :     dpns->appendrels = NULL;
     828             : 
     829             :     /* Assign a unique relation alias to each RTE */
     830       36690 :     set_rtable_names(dpns, parent_namespaces, NULL);
     831             : 
     832             :     /* Initialize dpns->rtable_columns to contain zeroed structs */
     833       36690 :     dpns->rtable_columns = NIL;
     834       81070 :     while (list_length(dpns->rtable_columns) < list_length(dpns->rtable))
     835       44380 :         dpns->rtable_columns = lappend(dpns->rtable_columns,
     836             :                                        palloc0(sizeof(deparse_columns)));
     837             : 
     838             :     /* If it's a utility query, it won't have a jointree */
     839       36690 :     if (query->jointree)
     840             :     {
     841             :         /* Detect whether global uniqueness of USING names is needed */
     842       36690 :         dpns->unique_using =
     843       36690 :             has_dangerous_join_using(dpns, (Node *) query->jointree);
     844             : 
     845             :         /*
     846             :          * Select names for columns merged by USING, via a recursive pass over
     847             :          * the query jointree.
     848             :          */
     849       36690 :         set_using_names(dpns, (Node *) query->jointree, NIL);
     850             :     }
     851             : 
     852             :     /*
     853             :      * Now assign remaining column aliases for each RTE.  We do this in a
     854             :      * linear scan of the rtable, so as to process RTEs whether or not they
     855             :      * are in the jointree (we mustn't miss NEW.*, INSERT target relations,
     856             :      * etc).  JOIN RTEs must be processed after their children, but this is
     857             :      * okay because they appear later in the rtable list than their children
     858             :      * (cf Asserts in identify_join_columns()).
     859             :      */
     860       81070 :     forboth(lc, dpns->rtable, lc2, dpns->rtable_columns)
     861             :     {
     862       44380 :         RangeTblEntry *rte = (RangeTblEntry *) lfirst(lc);
     863       44380 :         deparse_columns *colinfo = (deparse_columns *) lfirst(lc2);
     864             : 
     865       44380 :         if (rte->rtekind == RTE_JOIN)
     866        6532 :             set_join_column_names(dpns, rte, colinfo);
     867             :         else
     868       37848 :             set_relation_column_names(dpns, rte, colinfo);
     869             :     }
     870       36690 : }
     871             : 
     872             : /*
     873             :  * has_dangerous_join_using: search jointree for unnamed JOIN USING
     874             :  *
     875             :  * Merged columns of a JOIN USING may act differently from either of the input
     876             :  * columns, either because they are merged with COALESCE (in a FULL JOIN) or
     877             :  * because an implicit coercion of the underlying input column is required.
     878             :  * In such a case the column must be referenced as a column of the JOIN not as
     879             :  * a column of either input.  And this is problematic if the join is unnamed
     880             :  * (alias-less): we cannot qualify the column's name with an RTE name, since
     881             :  * there is none.  (Forcibly assigning an alias to the join is not a solution,
     882             :  * since that will prevent legal references to tables below the join.)
     883             :  * To ensure that every column in the query is unambiguously referenceable,
     884             :  * we must assign such merged columns names that are globally unique across
     885             :  * the whole query, aliasing other columns out of the way as necessary.
     886             :  *
     887             :  * Because the ensuing re-aliasing is fairly damaging to the readability of
     888             :  * the query, we don't do this unless we have to.  So, we must pre-scan
     889             :  * the join tree to see if we have to, before starting set_using_names().
     890             :  */
     891             : static bool
     892       76518 : has_dangerous_join_using(deparse_namespace *dpns, Node *jtnode)
     893             : {
     894       76518 :     if (IsA(jtnode, RangeTblRef))
     895             :     {
     896             :         /* nothing to do here */
     897             :     }
     898       43222 :     else if (IsA(jtnode, FromExpr))
     899             :     {
     900       36690 :         FromExpr   *f = (FromExpr *) jtnode;
     901             :         ListCell   *lc;
     902             : 
     903       63454 :         foreach(lc, f->fromlist)
     904             :         {
     905       26764 :             if (has_dangerous_join_using(dpns, (Node *) lfirst(lc)))
     906           0 :                 return true;
     907             :         }
     908             :     }
     909        6532 :     else if (IsA(jtnode, JoinExpr))
     910             :     {
     911        6532 :         JoinExpr   *j = (JoinExpr *) jtnode;
     912             : 
     913             :         /* Is it an unnamed JOIN with USING? */
     914        6532 :         if (j->alias == NULL && j->usingClause)
     915             :         {
     916             :             /*
     917             :              * Yes, so check each join alias var to see if any of them are not
     918             :              * simple references to underlying columns.  If so, we have a
     919             :              * dangerous situation and must pick unique aliases.
     920             :              */
     921           0 :             RangeTblEntry *jrte = rt_fetch(j->rtindex, dpns->rtable);
     922             : 
     923             :             /* We need only examine the merged columns */
     924           0 :             for (int i = 0; i < jrte->joinmergedcols; i++)
     925             :             {
     926           0 :                 Node       *aliasvar = list_nth(jrte->joinaliasvars, i);
     927             : 
     928           0 :                 if (!IsA(aliasvar, Var))
     929           0 :                     return true;
     930             :             }
     931             :         }
     932             : 
     933             :         /* Nope, but inspect children */
     934        6532 :         if (has_dangerous_join_using(dpns, j->larg))
     935           0 :             return true;
     936        6532 :         if (has_dangerous_join_using(dpns, j->rarg))
     937           0 :             return true;
     938             :     }
     939             :     else
     940           0 :         elog(ERROR, "unrecognized node type: %d",
     941             :              (int) nodeTag(jtnode));
     942       76518 :     return false;
     943             : }
     944             : 
     945             : /*
     946             :  * set_using_names: select column aliases to be used for merged USING columns
     947             :  *
     948             :  * We do this during a recursive descent of the query jointree.
     949             :  * dpns->unique_using must already be set to determine the global strategy.
     950             :  *
     951             :  * Column alias info is saved in the dpns->rtable_columns list, which is
     952             :  * assumed to be filled with pre-zeroed deparse_columns structs.
     953             :  *
     954             :  * parentUsing is a list of all USING aliases assigned in parent joins of
     955             :  * the current jointree node.  (The passed-in list must not be modified.)
     956             :  */
     957             : static void
     958       76518 : set_using_names(deparse_namespace *dpns, Node *jtnode, List *parentUsing)
     959             : {
     960       76518 :     if (IsA(jtnode, RangeTblRef))
     961             :     {
     962             :         /* nothing to do now */
     963             :     }
     964       43222 :     else if (IsA(jtnode, FromExpr))
     965             :     {
     966       36690 :         FromExpr   *f = (FromExpr *) jtnode;
     967             :         ListCell   *lc;
     968             : 
     969       63454 :         foreach(lc, f->fromlist)
     970       26764 :             set_using_names(dpns, (Node *) lfirst(lc), parentUsing);
     971             :     }
     972        6532 :     else if (IsA(jtnode, JoinExpr))
     973             :     {
     974        6532 :         JoinExpr   *j = (JoinExpr *) jtnode;
     975        6532 :         RangeTblEntry *rte = rt_fetch(j->rtindex, dpns->rtable);
     976        6532 :         deparse_columns *colinfo = deparse_columns_fetch(j->rtindex, dpns);
     977             :         int        *leftattnos;
     978             :         int        *rightattnos;
     979             :         deparse_columns *leftcolinfo;
     980             :         deparse_columns *rightcolinfo;
     981             :         int         i;
     982             :         ListCell   *lc;
     983             : 
     984             :         /* Get info about the shape of the join */
     985        6532 :         identify_join_columns(j, rte, colinfo);
     986        6532 :         leftattnos = colinfo->leftattnos;
     987        6532 :         rightattnos = colinfo->rightattnos;
     988             : 
     989             :         /* Look up the not-yet-filled-in child deparse_columns structs */
     990        6532 :         leftcolinfo = deparse_columns_fetch(colinfo->leftrti, dpns);
     991        6532 :         rightcolinfo = deparse_columns_fetch(colinfo->rightrti, dpns);
     992             : 
     993             :         /*
     994             :          * If this join is unnamed, then we cannot substitute new aliases at
     995             :          * this level, so any name requirements pushed down to here must be
     996             :          * pushed down again to the children.
     997             :          */
     998        6532 :         if (rte->alias == NULL)
     999             :         {
    1000        6532 :             for (i = 0; i < colinfo->num_cols; i++)
    1001             :             {
    1002           0 :                 char       *colname = colinfo->colnames[i];
    1003             : 
    1004           0 :                 if (colname == NULL)
    1005           0 :                     continue;
    1006             : 
    1007             :                 /* Push down to left column, unless it's a system column */
    1008           0 :                 if (leftattnos[i] > 0)
    1009             :                 {
    1010           0 :                     expand_colnames_array_to(leftcolinfo, leftattnos[i]);
    1011           0 :                     leftcolinfo->colnames[leftattnos[i] - 1] = colname;
    1012             :                 }
    1013             : 
    1014             :                 /* Same on the righthand side */
    1015           0 :                 if (rightattnos[i] > 0)
    1016             :                 {
    1017           0 :                     expand_colnames_array_to(rightcolinfo, rightattnos[i]);
    1018           0 :                     rightcolinfo->colnames[rightattnos[i] - 1] = colname;
    1019             :                 }
    1020             :             }
    1021             :         }
    1022             : 
    1023             :         /*
    1024             :          * If there's a USING clause, select the USING column names and push
    1025             :          * those names down to the children.  We have two strategies:
    1026             :          *
    1027             :          * If dpns->unique_using is true, we force all USING names to be
    1028             :          * unique across the whole query level.  In principle we'd only need
    1029             :          * the names of dangerous USING columns to be globally unique, but to
    1030             :          * safely assign all USING names in a single pass, we have to enforce
    1031             :          * the same uniqueness rule for all of them.  However, if a USING
    1032             :          * column's name has been pushed down from the parent, we should use
    1033             :          * it as-is rather than making a uniqueness adjustment.  This is
    1034             :          * necessary when we're at an unnamed join, and it creates no risk of
    1035             :          * ambiguity.  Also, if there's a user-written output alias for a
    1036             :          * merged column, we prefer to use that rather than the input name;
    1037             :          * this simplifies the logic and seems likely to lead to less aliasing
    1038             :          * overall.
    1039             :          *
    1040             :          * If dpns->unique_using is false, we only need USING names to be
    1041             :          * unique within their own join RTE.  We still need to honor
    1042             :          * pushed-down names, though.
    1043             :          *
    1044             :          * Though significantly different in results, these two strategies are
    1045             :          * implemented by the same code, with only the difference of whether
    1046             :          * to put assigned names into dpns->using_names.
    1047             :          */
    1048        6532 :         if (j->usingClause)
    1049             :         {
    1050             :             /* Copy the input parentUsing list so we don't modify it */
    1051           0 :             parentUsing = list_copy(parentUsing);
    1052             : 
    1053             :             /* USING names must correspond to the first join output columns */
    1054           0 :             expand_colnames_array_to(colinfo, list_length(j->usingClause));
    1055           0 :             i = 0;
    1056           0 :             foreach(lc, j->usingClause)
    1057             :             {
    1058           0 :                 char       *colname = strVal(lfirst(lc));
    1059             : 
    1060             :                 /* Assert it's a merged column */
    1061             :                 Assert(leftattnos[i] != 0 && rightattnos[i] != 0);
    1062             : 
    1063             :                 /* Adopt passed-down name if any, else select unique name */
    1064           0 :                 if (colinfo->colnames[i] != NULL)
    1065           0 :                     colname = colinfo->colnames[i];
    1066             :                 else
    1067             :                 {
    1068             :                     /* Prefer user-written output alias if any */
    1069           0 :                     if (rte->alias && i < list_length(rte->alias->colnames))
    1070           0 :                         colname = strVal(list_nth(rte->alias->colnames, i));
    1071             :                     /* Make it appropriately unique */
    1072           0 :                     colname = make_colname_unique(colname, dpns, colinfo);
    1073           0 :                     if (dpns->unique_using)
    1074           0 :                         dpns->using_names = lappend(dpns->using_names,
    1075             :                                                     colname);
    1076             :                     /* Save it as output column name, too */
    1077           0 :                     colinfo->colnames[i] = colname;
    1078             :                 }
    1079             : 
    1080             :                 /* Remember selected names for use later */
    1081           0 :                 colinfo->usingNames = lappend(colinfo->usingNames, colname);
    1082           0 :                 parentUsing = lappend(parentUsing, colname);

    1084             :                 /* Push down to left column, unless it's a system column */

    1086             :                 {
    1087           0 :                     expand_colnames_array_to(leftcolinfo, leftattnos[i]);

    1089             :                 }
    1090             : 
    1091             :                 /* Same on the righthand side */
    1092           0 :                 if (rightattnos[i] > 0)
    1093             :                 {
    1094           0 :                     expand_colnames_array_to(rightcolinfo, rightattnos[i]);
    1095           0 :                     rightcolinfo->colnames[rightattnos[i] - 1] = colname;
    1096             :                 }
    1097             : 
    1098           0 :                 i++;
    1099             :             }
    1100             :         }
    1101             : 
    1102             :         /* Mark child deparse_columns structs with correct parentUsing info */
    1103        6532 :         leftcolinfo->parentUsing = parentUsing;
    1104        6532 :         rightcolinfo->parentUsing = parentUsing;
    1105             : 
    1106             :         /* Now recursively assign USING column names in children */
    1107        6532 :         set_using_names(dpns, j->larg, parentUsing);
    1108        6532 :         set_using_names(dpns, j->rarg, parentUsing);
    1109             :     }
    1110             :     else
    1111           0 :         elog(ERROR, "unrecognized node type: %d",
    1112             :              (int) nodeTag(jtnode));
    1113       76518 : }
    1114             : 
    1115             : /*

    1172             :          * query was parsed.  If possible, use expandRTE() to handle that
    1173             :          * case, since it has the tedious logic needed to find out about
    1174             :          * dropped columns.  However, if we're explaining a plan, then we
    1175             :          * don't have rte->functions because the planner thinks that won't be
    1176             :          * needed later, and that breaks expandRTE().  So in that case we have
    1177             :          * to rely on rte->eref, which may lead us to report a dropped
    1178             :          * column's old name; that seems close enough for EXPLAIN's purposes.
    1179             :          *

    1411             :         }

    1413             :         /* Remember if any assigned aliases differ from "real" name */
    1414           0 :         if (!changed_any && strcmp(colname, real_colname) != 0)
    1415           0 :             changed_any = true;
    1416             :     }
    1417             : 
    1418             :     /*
    1419             :      * Calculate number of columns the join would have if it were re-parsed
    1420             :      * now, and create storage for the new_colnames and is_new_col arrays.
    1421             :      *
    1422             :      * Note: colname_is_unique will be consulting new_colnames[] during the
    1423             :      * loops below, so its not-yet-filled entries must be zeroes.
    1424             :      */

    1426        6532 :         list_length(colinfo->usingNames);
    1427        6532 :     colinfo->num_new_cols = nnewcolumns;
    1428        6532 :     colinfo->new_colnames = (char **) palloc0(nnewcolumns * sizeof(char *));
    1429        6532 :     colinfo->is_new_col = (bool *) palloc0(nnewcolumns * sizeof(bool));
    1430             : 
    1431             :     /*
    1432             :      * Generating the new_colnames array is a bit tricky since any new columns
    1433             :      * added since parse time must be inserted in the right places.  This code
    1434             :      * must match the parser, which will order a join's columns as merged
    1435             :      * columns first (in USING-clause order), then non-merged columns from the
    1436             :      * left input (in attnum order), then non-merged columns from the right
    1437             :      * input (ditto).  If one of the inputs is itself a join, its columns will
    1438             :      * be ordered according to the same rule, which means newly-added columns
    1439             :      * might not be at the end.  We can figure out what's what by consulting
    1440             :      * the leftattnos and rightattnos arrays plus the input is_new_col arrays.
    1441             :      *
    1442             :      * In these loops, i indexes leftattnos/rightattnos (so it's join varattno
    1443             :      * less one), j indexes new_colnames/is_new_col, and ic/jc have similar
    1444             :      * meanings for the current child RTE.
    1445             :      */
    1446             : 
    1447             :     /* Handle merged columns; they are first and can't be new */
    1448        6532 :     i = j = 0;
    1449        6532 :     while (i < noldcolumns &&
    1450        6532 :            colinfo->leftattnos[i] != 0 &&
    1451        6532 :            colinfo->rightattnos[i] != 0)
    1452             :     {
    1453             :         /* column name is already determined and known unique */
    1454           0 :         colinfo->new_colnames[j] = colinfo->colnames[i];
    1455           0 :         colinfo->is_new_col[j] = false;
    1456             : 
    1457             :         /* build bitmapsets of child attnums of merged columns */
    1458           0 :         if (colinfo->leftattnos[i] > 0)
    1459           0 :             leftmerged = bms_add_member(leftmerged, colinfo->leftattnos[i]);
    1460           0 :         if (colinfo->rightattnos[i] > 0)
    1461           0 :             rightmerged = bms_add_member(rightmerged, colinfo->rightattnos[i]);
    1462             : 
    1463           0 :         i++, j++;
    1464             :     }
    1465             : 
    1466             :     /* Handle non-merged left-child columns */

    1468       85662 :     for (jc = 0; jc < leftcolinfo->num_new_cols; jc++)
    1469             :     {
    1470       79130 :         char       *child_colname = leftcolinfo->new_colnames[jc];
    1471             : 
    1472       79130 :         if (!leftcolinfo->is_new_col[jc])
    1473             :         {

    1788             : /*
    1789             :  * set_deparse_plan: set up deparse_namespace to parse subexpressions
    1790             :  * of a given Plan node
    1791             :  *
    1792             :  * This sets the plan, outer_planstate, inner_planstate, outer_tlist,
    1793             :  * inner_tlist, and index_tlist fields.  Caller is responsible for adjusting
    1794             :  * the ancestors list if necessary.  Note that the rtable and ctes fields do
    1795             :  * not need to change when shifting attention to different plan nodes in a
    1796             :  * single plan tree.
    1797             :  */
    1798             : static void
    1799           0 : set_deparse_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, Plan *plan)
    1800             : {
    1801           0 :     dpns->plan = plan;
    1802             : 
    1803             :     /*
    1804             :      * We special-case Append and MergeAppend to pretend that the first child
    1805             :      * plan is the OUTER referent; we have to interpret OUTER Vars in their
    1806             :      * tlists according to one of the children, and the first one is the most
    1807             :      * natural choice.
    1808             :      */
    1809           0 :     if (IsA(plan, Append))
    1810           0 :         dpns->outer_plan = linitial(((Append *) plan)->appendplans);
    1811           0 :     else if (IsA(plan, MergeAppend))
    1812           0 :         dpns->outer_plan = linitial(((MergeAppend *) plan)->mergeplans);
    1813             :     else
    1814           0 :         dpns->outer_plan = outerPlan(plan);
    1815             : 
    1816           0 :     if (dpns->outer_plan)
    1817           0 :         dpns->outer_tlist = dpns->outer_plan->targetlist;
    1818             :     else
    1819           0 :         dpns->outer_tlist = NIL;
    1820             : 
    1821             :     /*
    1822             :      * For a SubqueryScan, pretend the subplan is INNER referent.  (We don't
    1823             :      * use OUTER because that could someday conflict with the normal meaning.)
    1824             :      * Likewise, for a CteScan, pretend the subquery's plan is INNER referent.
    1825             :      * For a WorkTableScan, locate the parent RecursiveUnion plan node and use
    1826             :      * that as INNER referent.
    1827             :      *
    1828             :      * For MERGE, make the inner tlist point to the merge source tlist, which
    1829             :      * is same as the targetlist that the ModifyTable's source plan provides.
    1830             :      * For ON CONFLICT .. UPDATE we just need the inner tlist to point to the
    1831             :      * excluded expression's tlist. (Similar to the SubqueryScan we don't want
    1832             :      * to reuse OUTER, it's used for RETURNING in some modify table cases,
    1833             :      * although not INSERT .. CONFLICT).
    1834             :      */
    1835           0 :     if (IsA(plan, SubqueryScan))
    1836           0 :         dpns->inner_plan = ((SubqueryScan *) plan)->subplan;
    1837           0 :     else if (IsA(plan, CteScan))
    1838           0 :         dpns->inner_plan = list_nth(dpns->subplans,
    1839           0 :                                     ((CteScan *) plan)->ctePlanId - 1);
    1840           0 :     else if (IsA(plan, WorkTableScan))
    1841           0 :         dpns->inner_plan = find_recursive_union(dpns,
    1842             :                                                 (WorkTableScan *) plan);
    1843           0 :     else if (IsA(plan, ModifyTable))
    1844           0 :         dpns->inner_plan = plan;
    1845             :     else
    1846           0 :         dpns->inner_plan = innerPlan(plan);
    1847             : 
    1848           0 :     if (IsA(plan, ModifyTable))
    1849             :     {
    1850           0 :         if (((ModifyTable *) plan)->operation == CMD_MERGE)
    1851           0 :             dpns->inner_tlist = dpns->outer_tlist;
    1852             :         else
    1853           0 :             dpns->inner_tlist = ((ModifyTable *) plan)->exclRelTlist;
    1854             :     }
    1855           0 :     else if (dpns->inner_plan)
    1856           0 :         dpns->inner_tlist = dpns->inner_plan->targetlist;
    1857             :     else
    1858           0 :         dpns->inner_tlist = NIL;
    1859             : 
    1860             :     /* Set up referent for INDEX_VAR Vars, if needed */
    1861           0 :     if (IsA(plan, IndexOnlyScan))
    1862           0 :         dpns->index_tlist = ((IndexOnlyScan *) plan)->indextlist;
    1863           0 :     else if (IsA(plan, ForeignScan))
    1864           0 :         dpns->index_tlist = ((ForeignScan *) plan)->fdw_scan_tlist;
    1865           0 :     else if (IsA(plan, CustomScan))
    1866           0 :         dpns->index_tlist = ((CustomScan *) plan)->custom_scan_tlist;
    1867             :     else
    1868           0 :         dpns->index_tlist = NIL;
    1869           0 : }
    1870             : 
    1871             : /*
    1872             :  * Locate the ancestor plan node that is the RecursiveUnion generating
    1873             :  * the WorkTableScan's work table.  We can match on wtParam, since that
    1874             :  * should be unique within the plan tree.
    1875             :  */
    1876             : static Plan *
    1877           0 : find_recursive_union(deparse_namespace *dpns, WorkTableScan *wtscan)
    1878             : {
    1879             :     ListCell   *lc;
    1880             : 
    1881           0 :     foreach(lc, dpns->ancestors)
    1882             :     {
    1883           0 :         Plan       *ancestor = (Plan *) lfirst(lc);
    1884             : 
    1885           0 :         if (IsA(ancestor, RecursiveUnion) &&
    1886           0 :             ((RecursiveUnion *) ancestor)->wtParam == wtscan->wtParam)
    1887           0 :             return ancestor;
    1888             :     }
    1889           0 :     elog(ERROR, "could not find RecursiveUnion for WorkTableScan with wtParam %d",
    1890             :          wtscan->wtParam);
    1891             :     return NULL;
    1892             : }
    1893             : 
    1894             : /*
    1895             :  * push_child_plan: temporarily transfer deparsing attention to a child plan
    1896             :  *
    1897             :  * When expanding an OUTER_VAR or INNER_VAR reference, we must adjust the
    1898             :  * deparse context in case the referenced expression itself uses
    1899             :  * OUTER_VAR/INNER_VAR.  We modify the top stack entry in-place to avoid
    1900             :  * affecting levelsup issues (although in a Plan tree there really shouldn't
    1901             :  * be any).
    1902             :  *
    1903             :  * Caller must provide a local deparse_namespace variable to save the
    1904             :  * previous state for pop_child_plan.
    1905             :  */
    1906             : static void
    1907           0 : push_child_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, Plan *plan,
    1908             :                 deparse_namespace *save_dpns)
    1909             : {
    1910             :     /* Save state for restoration later */
    1911           0 :     *save_dpns = *dpns;
    1912             : 
    1913             :     /* Link current plan node into ancestors list */
    1914           0 :     dpns->ancestors = lcons(dpns->plan, dpns->ancestors);
    1915             : 
    1916             :     /* Set attention on selected child */
    1917           0 :     set_deparse_plan(dpns, plan);
    1918           0 : }
    1919             : 
    1920             : /*
    1921             :  * pop_child_plan: undo the effects of push_child_plan
    1922             :  */
    1923             : static void
    1924           0 : pop_child_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, deparse_namespace *save_dpns)
    1925             : {
    1926             :     List       *ancestors;
    1927             : 
    1928             :     /* Get rid of ancestors list cell added by push_child_plan */
    1929           0 :     ancestors = list_delete_first(dpns->ancestors);
    1930             : 
    1931             :     /* Restore fields changed by push_child_plan */
    1932           0 :     *dpns = *save_dpns;
    1933             : 
    1934             :     /* Make sure dpns->ancestors is right (may be unnecessary) */
    1935           0 :     dpns->ancestors = ancestors;
    1936           0 : }
    1937             : 
    1938             : /*
    1939             :  * push_ancestor_plan: temporarily transfer deparsing attention to an
    1940             :  * ancestor plan
    1941             :  *
    1942             :  * When expanding a Param reference, we must adjust the deparse context
    1943             :  * to match the plan node that contains the expression being printed;
    1944             :  * otherwise we'd fail if that expression itself contains a Param or
    1945             :  * OUTER_VAR/INNER_VAR/INDEX_VAR variable.
    1946             :  *
    1947             :  * The target ancestor is conveniently identified by the ListCell holding it
    1948             :  * in dpns->ancestors.
    1949             :  *
    1950             :  * Caller must provide a local deparse_namespace variable to save the
    1951             :  * previous state for pop_ancestor_plan.
    1952             :  */
    1953             : static void
    1954           0 : push_ancestor_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, ListCell *ancestor_cell,
    1955             :                    deparse_namespace *save_dpns)
    1956             : {
    1957           0 :     Plan       *plan = (Plan *) lfirst(ancestor_cell);
    1958             : 
    1959             :     /* Save state for restoration later */
    1960           0 :     *save_dpns = *dpns;
    1961             : 
    1962             :     /* Build a new ancestor list with just this node's ancestors */
    1963           0 :     dpns->ancestors =
    1964           0 :         list_copy_tail(dpns->ancestors,
    1965           0 :                        list_cell_number(dpns->ancestors, ancestor_cell) + 1);
    1966             : 
    1967             :     /* Set attention on selected ancestor */
    1968           0 :     set_deparse_plan(dpns, plan);
    1969           0 : }
    1970             : 
    1971             : /*
    1972             :  * pop_ancestor_plan: undo the effects of push_ancestor_plan
    1973             :  */
    1974             : static void
    1975           0 : pop_ancestor_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, deparse_namespace *save_dpns)
    1976             : {
    1977             :     /* Free the ancestor list made in push_ancestor_plan */
    1978           0 :     list_free(dpns->ancestors);
    1979             : 
    1980             :     /* Restore fields changed by push_ancestor_plan */
    1981           0 :     *dpns = *save_dpns;
    1982           0 : }
    1983             : 
    1984             : /* ----------
    1985             :  * deparse_shard_query      - Parse back a query for execution on a shard
    1986             :  *
    1987             :  * Builds an SQL string to perform the provided query on a specific shard and
    1988             :  * places this string into the provided buffer.
    1989             :  * ----------
    1990             :  */
    1991             : void
    1992        2646 : deparse_shard_query(Query *query, Oid distrelid, int64 shardid,
    1993             :                     StringInfo buffer)
    1994             : {
    1995        2646 :     get_query_def_extended(query, buffer, NIL, distrelid, shardid, NULL,
    1996             :                            false,
    1997             :                            0, WRAP_COLUMN_DEFAULT, 0);
    1998        2646 : }
    1999             : 
    2000             : /* ----------
    2001             :  * get_query_def            - Parse back one query parsetree
    2002             :  *
    2003             :  * query: parsetree to be displayed
    2004             :  * buf: output text is appended to buf
    2005             :  * parentnamespace: list (initially empty) of outer-level deparse_namespace's
    2006             :  * resultDesc: if not NULL, the output tuple descriptor for the view
    2007             :  *      represented by a SELECT query.  We use the column names from it
    2008             :  *      to label SELECT output columns, in preference to names in the query
    2009             :  * colNamesVisible: true if the surrounding context cares about the output
    2010             :  *      column names at all (as, for example, an EXISTS() context does not);
    2011             :  *      when false, we can suppress dummy column labels such as "?column?"
    2012             :  * prettyFlags: bitmask of PRETTYFLAG_XXX options
    2013             :  * wrapColumn: maximum line length, or -1 to disable wrapping
    2014             :  * startIndent: initial indentation amount
    2015             :  * ----------
    2016             :  */
    2017             : static void
    2018       34044 : get_query_def(Query *query, StringInfo buf, List *parentnamespace,
    2019             :               TupleDesc resultDesc, bool colNamesVisible,
    2020             :               int prettyFlags, int wrapColumn, int startIndent)
    2021             : {
    2022       34044 :     get_query_def_extended(query, buf, parentnamespace, InvalidOid, 0, resultDesc,
    2023             :                            colNamesVisible,
    2024             :                            prettyFlags, wrapColumn, startIndent);
    2025       34044 : }
    2026             : 
    2027             : /* ----------
    2028             :  * get_query_def_extended       - Parse back one query parsetree, optionally
    2029             :  *                                with extension using a shard identifier.
    2030             :  *
    2031             :  * If distrelid is valid and shardid is positive, the provided shardid is added
    2032             :  * any time the provided relid is deparsed, so that the query may be executed
    2033             :  * on a placement for the given shard.
    2034             :  * ----------
    2035             :  */
    2036             : static void
    2037       36690 : get_query_def_extended(Query *query, StringInfo buf, List *parentnamespace,
    2038             :                        Oid distrelid, int64 shardid, TupleDesc resultDesc,
    2039             :                        bool colNamesVisible,
    2040             :                        int prettyFlags, int wrapColumn, int startIndent)
    2041             : {
    2042             :     deparse_context context;
    2043             :     deparse_namespace dpns;
    2044             : 
    2045             :     /* Guard against excessively long or deeply-nested queries */
    2046       36690 :     CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS();
    2047       36690 :     check_stack_depth();
    2048             : 
    2049             :     /*
    2050             :      * Before we begin to examine the query, acquire locks on referenced
    2051             :      * relations, and fix up deleted columns in JOIN RTEs.  This ensures
    2052             :      * consistent results.  Note we assume it's OK to scribble on the passed
    2053             :      * querytree!
    2054             :      *
    2055             :      * We are only deparsing the query (we are not about to execute it), so we
    2056             :      * only need AccessShareLock on the relations it mentions.
    2057             :      */
    2058       36690 :     AcquireRewriteLocks(query, false, false);
    2059             : 
    2060             :     /*
    2061             :      * Set search_path to NIL so that all objects outside of pg_catalog will be
    2062             :      * schema-prefixed. pg_catalog will be added automatically when we call
    2063             :      * PushEmptySearchPath().
    2064             :      */
    2065       36690 :     int saveNestLevel = PushEmptySearchPath();
    2066             : 
    2067       36690 :     context.buf = buf;
    2068       36690 :     context.namespaces = lcons(&dpns, list_copy(parentnamespace));
    2069       36690 :     context.windowClause = NIL;
    2070       36690 :     context.windowTList = NIL;
    2071       52326 :     context.varprefix = (parentnamespace != NIL ||
    2072       15636 :                          list_length(query->rtable) != 1);
    2073       36690 :     context.prettyFlags = prettyFlags;
    2074       36690 :     context.wrapColumn = wrapColumn;
    2075       36690 :     context.indentLevel = startIndent;
    2076       36690 :     context.special_exprkind = EXPR_KIND_NONE;
    2077       36690 :     context.appendparents = NULL;
    2078       36690 :     context.distrelid = distrelid;
    2079       36690 :     context.shardid = shardid;
    2080             : 
    2081       36690 :     set_deparse_for_query(&dpns, query, parentnamespace);
    2082             : 
    2083       36690 :     switch (query->commandType)
    2084             :     {
    2085       34044 :         case CMD_SELECT:
    2086       34044 :             get_select_query_def(query, &context, resultDesc, colNamesVisible);
    2087       34044 :             break;
    2088             : 
    2089           0 :         case CMD_UPDATE:
    2090           0 :             get_update_query_def(query, &context, colNamesVisible);
    2091           0 :             break;
    2092             : 
    2093        2646 :         case CMD_INSERT:
    2094        2646 :             get_insert_query_def(query, &context, colNamesVisible);
    2095        2646 :             break;
    2096             : 
    2097           0 :         case CMD_DELETE:
    2098           0 :             get_delete_query_def(query, &context, colNamesVisible);
    2099           0 :             break;
    2100             : 
    2101           0 :         case CMD_MERGE:
    2102           0 :             get_merge_query_def(query, &context);
    2103           0 :             break;
    2104             : 
    2105           0 :         case CMD_NOTHING:
    2106           0 :             appendStringInfoString(buf, "NOTHING");
    2107           0 :             break;
    2108             : 
    2109           0 :         case CMD_UTILITY:
    2110           0 :             get_utility_query_def(query, &context);
    2111           0 :             break;
    2112             : 
    2113           0 :         default:
    2114           0 :             elog(ERROR, "unrecognized query command type: %d",
    2115             :                  query->commandType);
    2116             :             break;
    2117             :     }
    2118             : 
    2119             :     /* revert back to original search_path */
    2120       36690 :     PopEmptySearchPath(saveNestLevel);
    2121       36690 : }

    2393             : 
    2394             :             /* don't print implicit clauses */

    2398           0 :             switch (rc->strength)
    2399             :             {
    2400           0 :                 case LCS_NONE:
    2401             :                     /* we intentionally throw an error for LCS_NONE */
    2402           0 :                     elog(ERROR, "unrecognized LockClauseStrength %d",

    2437             : /*
    2438             :  * Detect whether query looks like SELECT ... FROM VALUES();
    2439             :  * if so, return the VALUES RTE.  Otherwise return NULL.
    2440             :  */
    2441             : static RangeTblEntry *
    2442       33091 : get_simple_values_rte(Query *query, TupleDesc resultDesc)
    2443             : {
    2444       33091 :     RangeTblEntry *result = NULL;
    2445             :     ListCell   *lc;
    2446             :     int colno;
    2447             : 
    2448             :     /*
    2449             :      * We want to return true even if the Query also contains OLD or NEW rule
    2450             :      * RTEs.  So the idea is to scan the rtable and see if there is only one
    2451             :      * inFromCl RTE that is a VALUES RTE.
    2452             :      */
    2453       33091 :     foreach(lc, query->rtable)
    2454             :     {
    2455       26764 :         RangeTblEntry *rte = (RangeTblEntry *) lfirst(lc);
    2456             : 
    2457       26764 :         if (rte->rtekind == RTE_VALUES && rte->inFromCl)
    2458             :         {
    2459           0 :             if (result)
    2460       26764 :                 return NULL;    /* multiple VALUES (probably not possible) */
    2461           0 :             result = rte;
    2462             :         }
    2463       26764 :         else if (rte->rtekind == RTE_RELATION && !rte->inFromCl)
    2464           0 :             continue;           /* ignore rule entries */
    2465             :         else
    2466       26764 :             return NULL;        /* something else -> not simple VALUES */
    2467             :     }
    2468             : 
    2469             :     /*
    2470             :      * We don't need to check the targetlist in any great detail, because
    2471             :      * parser/analyze.c will never generate a "bare" VALUES RTE --- they only
    2472             :      * appear inside auto-generated sub-queries with very restricted
    2473             :      * structure.  However, DefineView might have modified the tlist by
    2474             :      * injecting new column aliases; so compare tlist resnames against the
    2475             :      * RTE's names to detect that.
    2476             :      */

    2478             :     {
    2479             :         ListCell   *lcn;
    2480             : 
    2481           0 :         if (list_length(query->targetList) != list_length(result->eref->colnames))

    2483           0 :         colno = 0;
    2484           0 :         forboth(lc, query->targetList, lcn, result->eref->colnames)
    2485             :         {

    2488             :             char       *colname;
    2489             : 
    2490           0 :             if (tle->resjunk)
    2491           0 :                 return NULL;    /* this probably cannot happen */

    2634             : /* ----------

    2645             : {

    2651             :     ListCell   *l;
    2652             : 
    2653             :     /* we use targetbuf to hold each TLE's text temporarily */
    2654       33091 :     initStringInfo(&targetbuf);
    2655             : 
    2656       33091 :     sep = " ";
    2657       33091 :     colno = 0;
    2658      163844 :     foreach(l, targetList)
    2659             :     {

    2661             :         char       *colname;

    2668      130753 :         sep = ", ";
    2669      130753 :         colno++;

    2671             :         /*
    2672             :          * Put the new field text into targetbuf so we can decide after we've
    2673             :          * got it whether or not it needs to go on a new line.
    2674             :          */
    2675      130753 :         resetStringInfo(&targetbuf);
    2676      130753 :         context->buf = &targetbuf;
    2677             : 
    2678             :         /*
    2679             :          * We special-case Var nodes rather than using get_rule_expr. This is
    2680             :          * needed because get_rule_expr will display a whole-row Var as
    2681             :          * "foo.*", which is the preferred notation in most contexts, but at
    2682             :          * the top level of a SELECT list it's not right (the parser will
    2683             :          * expand that notation into multiple columns, yielding behavior
    2684             :          * different from a whole-row Var).  We need to call get_variable
    2685             :          * directly so that we can tell it to do the right thing, and so that
    2686             :          * we can get the attribute name which is the default AS label.
    2687             :          */
    2688      130753 :         if (tle->expr && (IsA(tle->expr, Var)))
    2689             :         {

    2691             :         }
    2692             :         else
    2693             :         {
    2694      103938 :             get_rule_expr((Node *) tle->expr, context, true);
    2695             : 
    2696             :             /*

    2700             :              */

    2703             :

    2778             : static void
    2779        2859 : get_setop_query(Node *setOp, Query *query, deparse_context *context,
    2780             :                 TupleDesc resultDesc, bool colNamesVisible)
    2781             : {
    2782        2859 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;

    2785             :     /* Guard against excessively long or deeply-nested queries */

    2789        2859 :     if (IsA(setOp, RangeTblRef))
    2790             :     {

    2792        1906 :         RangeTblEntry *rte = rt_fetch(rtr->rtindex, query->rtable);
    2793        1906 :         Query      *subquery = rte->subquery;

    2799        1906 :                       subquery->sortClause ||

    2802        1906 :                       subquery->limitCount);

    2804           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');

    2807             :                       context->prettyFlags, context->wrapColumn,
    2808             :                       context->indentLevel);
    2809        1906 :         if (need_paren)
    2810           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');

    2813             :     {
    2814         953 :         SetOperationStmt *op = (SetOperationStmt *) setOp;
    2815             :         int         subindent;
    2816             : 
    2817             :         /*
    2818             :          * We force parens when nesting two SetOperationStmts, except when the
    2819             :          * lefthand input is another setop of the same kind.  Syntactically,
    2820             :          * we could omit parens in rather more cases, but it seems best to use
    2821             :          * parens to flag cases where the setop operator changes.  If we use
    2822             :          * parens, we also increase the indentation level for the child query.
    2823             :          *
    2824             :          * There are some cases in which parens are needed around a leaf query
    2825             :          * too, but those are more easily handled at the next level down (see
    2826             :          * code above).
    2827             :          */
    2828         953 :         if (IsA(op->larg, SetOperationStmt))
    2829             :         {
    2830           0 :             SetOperationStmt *lop = (SetOperationStmt *) op->larg;

    2832           0 :             if (op->op == lop->op && op->all == lop->all)
    2833           0 :                 need_paren = false;
    2834             :             else
    2835           0 :                 need_paren = true;
    2836             :         }
    2837             :         else
    2838         953 :             need_paren = false;
    2839             : 
    2840         953 :         if (need_paren)
    2841             :         {
    2842           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');
    2843           0 :             subindent = PRETTYINDENT_STD;
    2844           0 :             appendContextKeyword(context, "", subindent, 0, 0);
    2845             :         }

    2851         953 :         if (need_paren)
    2852           0 :             appendContextKeyword(context, ") ", -subindent, 0, 0);

    2854           0 :             appendContextKeyword(context, "", -subindent, 0, 0);

    2865         329 :                 break;

    2883             :          */
    2884         953 :         if (need_paren)
    2885             :         {
