    7691             : /* ----------
    7692             :  * get_from_clause          - Parse back a FROM clause
    7693             :  *
    7694             :  * "prefix" is the keyword that denotes the start of the list of FROM
    7695             :  * elements. It is FROM when used to parse back SELECT and UPDATE, but
    7696             :  * is USING when parsing back DELETE.
    7697             :  * ----------
    7698             :  */
    7699             : static void
    7700       33091 : get_from_clause(Query *query, const char *prefix, deparse_context *context)
    7701             : {
    7702       33091 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    7703       33091 :     bool        first = true;
    7704             :     ListCell   *l;
    7705             : 
    7706             :     /*
    7707             :      * We use the query's jointree as a guide to what to print.  However, we
    7708             :      * must ignore auto-added RTEs that are marked not inFromCl. (These can
    7709             :      * only appear at the top level of the jointree, so it's sufficient to
    7710             :      * check here.)  This check also ensures we ignore the rule pseudo-RTEs
    7711             :      * for NEW and OLD.
    7712             :      */
    7713       59855 :     foreach(l, query->jointree->fromlist)
    7714             :     {
    7715       26764 :         Node       *jtnode = (Node *) lfirst(l);
    7716             : 
    7717       26764 :         if (IsA(jtnode, RangeTblRef))
    7718             :         {
    7719       24447 :             int         varno = ((RangeTblRef *) jtnode)->rtindex;
    7720       24447 :             RangeTblEntry *rte = rt_fetch(varno, query->rtable);
    7721             : 
    7722       24447 :             if (!rte->inFromCl)
    7723           0 :                 continue;
    7724             :         }
    7725             : 
    7726       26764 :         if (first)
    7727             :         {
    7728       26764 :             appendContextKeyword(context, prefix,
    7729             :                                  -PRETTYINDENT_STD, PRETTYINDENT_STD, 2);
    7730       26764 :             first = false;
    7731             : 
    7732       26764 :             get_from_clause_item(jtnode, query, context);
    7733             :         }
    7734             :         else
    7735             :         {
    7736             :             StringInfoData itembuf;
    7737             : 
    7738           0 :             appendStringInfoString(buf, ", ");
    7739             : 
    7740             :             /*
    7741             :              * Put the new FROM item's text into itembuf so we can decide
    7742             :              * after we've got it whether or not it needs to go on a new line.
    7743             :              */
    7744           0 :             initStringInfo(&itembuf);
    7745           0 :             context->buf = &itembuf;
    7746             : 
    7747           0 :             get_from_clause_item(jtnode, query, context);
    7748             : 
    7749             :             /* Restore context's output buffer */
    7750           0 :             context->buf = buf;
    7751             : 
    7752             :             /* Consider line-wrapping if enabled */
    7753           0 :             if (PRETTY_INDENT(context) && context->wrapColumn >= 0)
    7754             :             {
    7755             :                 /* Does the new item start with a new line? */
    7756           0 :                 if (itembuf.len > 0 && itembuf.data[0] == '\n')
    7757             :                 {
    7758             :                     /* If so, we shouldn't add anything */
    7759             :                     /* instead, remove any trailing spaces currently in buf */
    7760           0 :                     removeStringInfoSpaces(buf);

    7763             :                 {

    7766             :                     /* Locate the start of the current line in the buffer */

    7771           0 :                         trailing_nl++;

    7773             :                     /*

    7775             :                      * would cause an overflow.
    7776             :                      */

    7783             :

    7793             : static void
    7794       39828 : get_from_clause_item(Node *jtnode, Query *query, deparse_context *context)

    7852             : 
    7853             :                 /*
    7854             :                  * Omit ROWS FROM() syntax for just one function, unless it
    7855             :                  * has both a coldeflist and WITH ORDINALITY. If it has both,
    7856             :                  * we must use ROWS FROM() syntax to avoid ambiguity about
    7857             :                  * whether the coldeflist includes the ordinality column.
    7858             :                  */

    7860        6656 :                     (rtfunc1->funccolnames == NIL || !rte->funcordinality))

    7866             :                 {

    7868             :                     ListCell   *lc;
    7869             : 
    7870             :                     /*
    7871             :                      * If all the function calls in the list are to unnest,
    7872             :                      * and none need a coldeflist, then collapse the list back
    7873             :                      * down to UNNEST(args).  (If we had more than one
    7874             :                      * built-in unnest function, this would get more
    7875             :                      * difficult.)
    7876             :                      *
    7877             :                      * XXX This is pretty ugly, since it makes not-terribly-
    7878             :                      * future-proof assumptions about what the parser would do
    7879             :                      * with the output; but the alternative is to emit our
    7880             :                      * nonstandard ROWS FROM() notation for what might have
    7881             :                      * been a perfectly spec-compliant multi-argument
    7882             :                      * UNNEST().
    7883             :                      */
    7884           0 :                     all_unnest = true;

    7893           0 :                             all_unnest = false;
    7894           0 :                             break;

    7896             :                     }

    7957           0 :                 elog(ERROR, "unrecognized RTE kind: %d", (int) rte->rtekind);

    7960             :

    8195             : /*
    8196             :  * get_from_clause_coldeflist - reproduce FROM clause coldeflist
    8197             :  *
    8198             :  * When printing a top-level coldeflist (which is syntactically also the
    8199             :  * relation's column alias list), use column names from colinfo.  But when
    8200             :  * printing a coldeflist embedded inside ROWS FROM(), we prefer to use the
    8201             :  * original coldeflist's names, which are available in rtfunc->funccolnames.
    8202             :  * Pass NULL for colinfo to select the latter behavior.
    8203             :  *
    8204             :  * The coldeflist is appended immediately (no space) to buf.  Caller is
    8205             :  * responsible for ensuring that an alias or AS is present before it.

    8334             : /*
    8335             :  * processIndirection - take care of array and subfield assignment
    8336             :  *
    8337             :  * We strip any top-level FieldStore or assignment SubscriptingRef nodes that
    8338             :  * appear in the input, printing them as decoration for the base column
    8339             :  * name (which we assume the caller just printed).  We might also need to
    8340             :  * strip CoerceToDomain nodes, but only ones that appear above assignment
    8341             :  * nodes.
    8342             :  *
    8343             :  * Returns the subexpression that's to be assigned.
    8344             :  */

    8446             : /*
    8447             :  * get_relation_name
    8448             :  *      Get the unqualified name of a relation specified by OID
    8449             :  *
    8450             :  * This differs from the underlying get_rel_name() function in that it will

    8463             : /*
    8464             :  * generate_relation_or_shard_name
    8465             :  *      Compute the name to display for a relation or shard
    8466             :  *
    8467             :  * If the provided relid is equal to the provided distrelid, this function
    8468             :  * returns a shard-extended relation name; otherwise, it falls through to a
    8469             :  * simple generate_relation_name call.
    8470             :  */

    8608             : /*
    8609             :  * generate_function_name
    8610             :  *      Compute the name to display for a function specified by OID,
    8611             :  *      given that it is being called with the specified actual arg names and
    8612             :  *      types.  (Those matter because of ambiguous-function resolution rules.)
    8613             :  *
    8614             :  * If we're dealing with a potentially variadic function (in practice, this
    8615             :  * means a FuncExpr or Aggref, not some other way of calling a function), then
    8616             :  * has_variadic must specify whether variadic arguments have been merged,
    8617             :  * and *use_variadic_p will be set to indicate whether to print VARIADIC in
    8618             :  * the output.  For non-FuncExpr cases, has_variadic should be false and
    8619             :  * use_variadic_p can be NULL.
    8620             :  *
    8621             :  * The result includes all necessary quoting and schema-prefixing.
    8622             :  */

    8646       12480 :     procform = (Form_pg_proc) GETSTRUCT(proctup);
    8647       12480 :     proname = NameStr(procform->proname);
    8648             : 
    8649             :     /*

    8651             :      * qualification in some special cases.
    8652             :      */

    8654             :     {
    8655           0 :         if (strcmp(proname, "cube") == 0 || strcmp(proname, "rollup") == 0)
    8656           0 :             force_qualify = true;
    8657             :     }
    8658             : 
    8659             :     /*
    8660             :      * Determine whether VARIADIC should be printed.  We must do this first
    8661             :      * since it affects the lookup rules in func_get_detail().
    8662             :      *
    8663             :      * Currently, we always print VARIADIC if the function has a merged
    8664             :      * variadic-array argument.  Note that this is always the case for
    8665             :      * functions taking a VARIADIC argument type other than VARIADIC ANY.
    8666             :      *
    8667             :      * In principle, if VARIADIC wasn't originally specified and the array
    8668             :      * actual argument is deconstructable, we could print the array elements
    8669             :      * separately and not print VARIADIC, thus more nearly reproducing the
    8670             :      * original input.  For the moment that seems like too much complication
    8671             :      * for the benefit, and anyway we do not know whether VARIADIC was
    8672             :      * originally specified if it's a non-ANY type.
    8673             :      */
    8674       12480 :     if (use_variadic_p)
    8675             :     {

    8678       12480 :         use_variadic = has_variadic;
    8679       12480 :         *use_variadic_p = use_variadic;

    8686             : 
    8687             :     /*
    8688             :      * The idea here is to schema-qualify only if the parser would fail to
    8689             :      * resolve the correct function given the unqualified func name with the

    8691             :      * force qualification, then we can skip the lookup and pretend we didn't

    8693             :      */

    8697       12480 :                                    !use_variadic, true, false,
